plausible_answers.text: Fear of advances by the nationalist parties

qas.question: What led to the promotion of a report from the Scottish Office?
What left Callaghan leading a majority government?
Why did Callaghan trade with the larger parties?
What arrangement lasted longer than one year?
What shortened the life of the government?

context: <b0_0>Fear of advances by the nationalist parties<b0_0/>, particularly in Scotland, led to the suppression of a report from Scottish Office economist Gavin McCrone that suggested that an independent Scotland would be 'chronically in surplus'. By 1977 <b1_0>by-election losses<b1_0/> and defections to the breakaway Scottish Labour Party left Callaghan heading a minority government, forced to trade with smaller parties in order <b2_0>to govern<b2_0/>. An arrangement negotiated in 1977 with Liberal leader David Steel, known as the <b3_0>Lib-Lab Pact<b3_0/>, ended after one year. <b4_0>Deals<b4_0/> were then forged with various small parties including the Scottish National Party and the Welsh nationalist Plaid Cymru, prolonging the life of the government.
